sentences: George Mackay Brown was born on 17 October 1921, the youngest of six children.
The family had a history of depression and Mackay's uncle, Jimmy Brown, may have committed suicide: his body was found in Stromness harbour in 1935.
He started work in 1944 with The Orkney Herald, writing on Stromness news, and soon became a prolific journalist.
He was encouraged in writing poetry by Francis Scarfe, who was billeted in the Browns' house for over a year from April 1944.
In 1947, Stromness voted to allow pubs to open again, the town having been "dry" since the 1920s.
In 1947, Stromness voted to allow pubs to open again, the town having been "dry" since the 1920s.
When the first bar opened in 1948, Mackay Brown first tasted alcohol.
Having had poems published in several periodicals, his first volume of them, The Storm, appeared with the Orkney Press in 1954.

In 1969, his short-story collection A Time to Keep received a positive welcome.
This was also the year in which he finished working on a six-part cycle of poems about Rackwick, published in 1971 as Fishermen with Ploughs.
During the summer of 1970, Brown met the musician Peter Maxwell Davies in Rackwick.
When the novel was published in May 1972 it appeared prophetic because of the oil exploration beginning in the Orkney area.
The story of the life of Magnus Erlendsson, Earl of Orkney was one to which Brown frequently turned, and it was the theme of his next novel, Magnus, published in 1973.
Brown was awarded an OBE in the 1974 New Year Honours List.
Yet he maintained a stream of writing: poetry, children's stories, and a weekly column in the local newspaper, The Orcadian, which ran from 1971 to the end of his life.
A first selection of them appeared as Letter from Hamnavoe in 1975.
He said in early 1977 that this had been his most productive winter as a writer.
By early 1977, he was entering a period of depression which lasted intermittently for almost a decade, but maintained his working routine throughout.
He also suffered from severe bronchial problems, his condition becoming so serious that in early 1981 he was given the Last Sacraments.
Norah Smallwood, who had worked for his publishers Chatto & Windus and helped and encouraged him over the years, died in 1984.

Between 1987 and 1989, Brown travelled to Nairn, including a visit to Pluscarden Abbey, to Shetland and to Oxford, making it the longest time he had left Orkney since his earlier studies in Edinburgh.
Shortly afterwards, Brown was diagnosed with bowel cancer, which required two major operations in 1990 and a lengthy stay in Foresterhill Hospital, Aberdeen.
It won the Saltire Scottish Book of the Year Award for 1994 and was listed for the Booker prize for fiction, which caused Brown acute anxiety.

In 2005, a memorial plaque to Brown was unveiled at the Writers' Museum in the Royal Mile, Edinburgh.

A literary biography, Interrogation of Silence by Rowena Murray and Brian Murray, ensued in 2004, George Mackay Brown: The Life, a more personal biography by Maggie Fergusson, in 2006, and George Mackay Brown: The Wound and the Gift by Ron Ferguson, a study of Brown's spiritual journey including his controversial move from Presbyterianism to Roman Catholicism, in 2011.

During his last years Brown remained in his home, cared for by a network of friends, including Surinder Punjya (later principal of The Nesbitt Centre, Hong Kong), Gunnie Moberg, and Renée Simm.
In his final years Brown wrote two more novels, Vinland and Beside the Ocean of Time.
By the late 1960s Brown's poetry was renowned internationally, so that the American poet Robert Lowell, for example, came to Orkney expressly to meet him.
The year 1968 also saw his one visit to Ireland, on a bursary from the Society of Authors.
Brown was a mature student at Newbattle Abbey College in the 1951–1952 session, where the poet Edwin Muir, who had a great influence on his life as a writer, was warden.
